awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track E: Next Generation Biomaterials with Engineered Biodegradability to Enable Networked Swarm Sensing in the Ocean
awd_abstract_narration:
OIA - 2137561	NSF Convergence Accelerator Track E: Next generation biomaterials with engineered biodegradability to enable networked swarm sensing in the ocean
Abstract
This research focuses on marine debris management to facilitate a more sustainable engagement with the ocean. It embodies a Convergence Research approach by bringing together a team of microbiologists, materials scientists, engineers, and oceanographers from four academic institutions collaborating with industry partners from the oceanographic instrumentation sector and government experts. Today, plastics are a $4-trillion industry; but less than 1% are bioplastics. This project will pioneer a novel approach to designing materials for the marine environment by explicitly considering the metabolism of microbes in the environment in which they are expected to biodegrade. Expendable, networked, free-drifting instruments are revolutionizing ocean observation, but these growing fleets of sensors present an environmental challenge and require a necessary shift in how society thinks about the materials used in their construction. At present, most “biodegradable” plastics have limited biodegradation in cold, dark oceanic conditions and were designed and tested only in industrial composting facilities. This project will develop both sustainable materials and testing standards that accurately reflect ocean conditions. The successful development of materials designed to rapidly degrade in seawater is expected to transform multiple marine sectors, such as fisheries, and permeate wider industry applications where marine pollution by plastics is of major concern.
The research team will pioneer the embedding of live PHA-degrading marine bacteria directly into plastic materials by developing strategies for extending the viability of living cells in printed materials. The field-deployable respiration chamber developed as part of this project is expected to set a new industry standard for testing materials used in the marine environment. Materials that facilitate rapid degradation of marine instrumentation under realistic environmental conditions would transform society’s ability to deploy swarm sensors at scale. Solving this problem requires the convergence of intellectually distinct fields and approaches, as well as the involvement of stakeholders that manage marine debris and end-users. The research team will innovate, test, and integrate biomaterials designed to rapidly degrade at end-of-life in oceanic conditions. The project will develop a suite of novel plastic materials purpose-built for the marine environment by 3D printing living bacteria into the biopolymer polyhydroxyalkanoate (PHA), optimized with additives to supplement microbial metabolism. Second, it will modify existing marine instrumentation to produce a chamber for directly measuring the respiration of plastic materials in deep ocean environments. Finally, the research team will work with end users to prototype products designed to be deployed in the marine environment. The overarching objective of the project is to integrate sustainable materials into oceanographic instrument applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our team worked with industry partners to innovate, test, and integrate biomaterials designed to rapidly degrade at end-of-life in oceanic conditions with the potential to impact all sectors of the Blue Economy. Our activities during this Phase I project laid the foundation for our successful Phase II proposal, from which we expect the majority of the societal outcomes from this project to arise.

As a maritime nation, American security, commerce, and industry are directly dependent on our ability to observe and predict the ocean. Increasingly, this challenge is met using large fleets of autonomous, networked sensors that are left behind to accumulate as waste in the ocean. The marine sector is no different from other industries in its slow adoption of biodegradable materials, favoring conventional plastics for their lower price, familiarity, and proven performance. Additionally, most “biodegradable” plastics (such as polylactic acid, PLA) have limited biodegradation in cold, dark oceanic conditions and were designed and tested only for disposal in industrial composting facilities. Indeed, current standards for biodegradability in the marine environment define biodegradability at 30º C; 99% of the ocean’s volume is colder than this. Our project embodied a Convergence Research approach by bringing together a team of microbiologists, materials scientists, engineers, and oceanographers from academia, with industry partners from the bioplastics and oceanographic instrumentation sectors, government and non-profit sector experts in marine debris management.

Four core team members participated in the NSF Innovation Curriculum during Phase I. We learned about, and then implemented, user discovery, human-centered design, and team science practices. 

We conducted 21 interviews with potential end-users (oceanographic instrument manufacturers, commercial fishers, aquaculturists, an ocean-racing sailing organization, coastline restoration non-profits, government-led ocean observing programs), stakeholders (government regulators, oceanographers), and inspirational projects (scientists). In our first round of interviews, we learned from instrument manufacturers about their customer base, item lifespans, and different plastic forming methods, which solidified our hunch that there is a large demand for biodegradable materials in expendable instruments, even outside of academic oceanography (e.g. oil and gas exploration). From aquaculturists (oyster farmers), we learned about their need for durable plastic products, rather than degradable products. Finally, from government regulators, we heard that coastal management agencies will likely require the incorporation of biodegradable plastics in coastal development as soon as they are available. For our second round of interviews, we developed low-fidelity prototypes to show end-users and get further feedback about our ideas for how to accelerate and measure degradation. These prototypes included a “menu” of hypothetical materials with different degradation timescales and shelf lives, 3D printing filament and test samples made using additive manufacturing, adhesive living material “stickers” that can be made from 3D printed PHB-degrading bacteria, and real data on degradation rates and respiration of PHB.

Our accelerated collaboration led to multiple tangible products in Phase I. We developed the first extruded PHB filament from PHB material, suitable for additive manufacturing and 3D printing. We successfully 3D printed PHB-degrading bacteria into an adhesive hydrogel “sticker” that retains its PHB depolymerase activity even when transferred to a new surface, for which a provisional patent has since been filed. We isolated seven marine PHB-degrading bacteria, and piloted high-throughput respirometry methods to determine the rate constants for PHB in seawater at relevant temperatures. Finally, we used carbon dioxide-based respirometry to demonstrate degradability of PHB using ASTM standard methods. 

We also took what we learned in the NSF Convergence Accelerator curriculum to develop team marketing materials to facilitate commercialization of our new technology.

UCSB is a Hispanic-Serving Institution, and our five team leads identify as female or LGBTQIA, giving us extensive experience engaging underrepresented groups in research. Through this project, we partnered with the UCSB Center for Science and Engineering Partnerships (CSEP), the URI REU (SURFO) and EPSCoR (SURF) programs, and Kearns Center for Leadership and Diversity at UR to create new opportunities for academic research and workforce training to increase participation of individuals from underrepresented groups. We developed a successful intern recruitment and selection strategy that resulted in a diverse applicant pool and the selection of two female Hispanic interns who received training in research, followed by three months of workforce training.
